    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/wireshark-tutorial-examining-ursnif-infections/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><p><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386/">Ursnif</a> is banking malware sometimes referred to as Gozi or IFSB. The Ursnif family of malware has been active for years, and current samples generate distinct traffic patterns.</p>
<p>This tutorial reviews packet captures (pcaps) of infection Ursnif traffic using <a href="https://www.wireshark.org">Wireshark</a>. Understanding these traffic patterns can be critical for security professionals when detecting and investigating Ursnif infections.</p>
<p>This tutorial covers the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Ursnif distribution methods</li>
<li>Categories of Ursnif traffic</li>
<li>Five examples of pcaps from Ursnif infections</li>
</ul>
<p>Note: This tutorial assumes you have a basic knowledge of Wireshark, and it uses a customized column display shown in <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-customizing-wireshark-changing-column-display/">this tutorial</a>. You should also have experience with Wireshark display filters as described in <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-wireshark-display-filter-expressions/">this additional tutorial</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-102527-_xpnqwnxev0ry"></a>Ursnif Distribution Methods</h2>
<p>Ursnif can be distributed through web-based infection chains and malicious spam (malspam). In some cases, Ursnif is a follow-up infection caused by different malware families like <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-compromised-servers-fraud-accounts-recent-hancitor-attacks/">Hancitor</a>, as reported in <a href="https://isc.sans.edu/forums/diary/Hancitor+infection+with+Pony+Evil+Pony+Ursnif+and+Cobalt+Strike/25532/">this recent example</a>.</p>
<p>We frequently find examples of Ursnif from malspam-based distribution campaigns, such as the example in Figure 1.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2500" height="1443"  class="wp-image-102528 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-42.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-42.jpeg 2500w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-42-300x173.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-42-1024x591.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-42-768x443.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-42-1536x887.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-42-2048x1182.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-42-900x519.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-42-370x214.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2500px) 100vw, 2500px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 1. Flowchart from one of the more common Ursnif distribution campaigns.</em></span></p>
<h2><a id="post-102527-_hv2sjexuw7y9"></a>Categories of Ursnif Traffic</h2>
<p>This tutorial covers two categories of Ursnif infection traffic:</p>
<ul>
<li>Ursnif without HTTPS post-infection traffic</li>
<li>Ursnif with HTTPS post-infection traffic</li>
</ul>
<p>Malware samples from either of these categories create the same type of artifacts on an infected Windows host. For example, both types of Ursnif remain persistent on a Windows host by updating the Windows registry, such as the example shown in Figure 2.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2032" height="1016"  class="wp-image-102530 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-43.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-43.jpeg 2032w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-43-300x150.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-43-1024x512.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-43-768x384.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-43-1536x768.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-43-900x450.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-43-370x185.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2032px) 100vw, 2032px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 2. Example of Windows registry updates caused by samples of Ursnif, either with or without HTTPS post-infection traffic.</em></span></p>
<h2><a id="post-102527-_vx0grm3szcka"></a>Example 1: Ursnif without HTTPS</h2>
<p>The first pcap for this tutorial, <strong><em>Ursnif-traffic-example-1.pcap</em></strong>, is available <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/training/examining-ursnif.html">here</a>. The chain of events behind this traffic was tweeted <a href="https://twitter.com/malware_traffic/status/1203071348941246464">here</a>. Example 1 has been stripped of all traffic not directly related to the Ursnif infection.</p>
<p>Open the pcap in Wireshark and filter on <strong><em>http.request</em></strong> as shown in Figure 3.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2334" height="1326"  class="wp-image-102532 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-44.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-44.jpeg 2334w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-44-300x170.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-44-1024x582.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-44-768x436.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-44-1536x873.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-44-2048x1164.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-44-900x511.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-44-370x210.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2334px) 100vw, 2334px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 3. The pcap for example 1 filtered in Wireshark.</em></span></p>
<p>In this example, the Ursnif-infected host generates post-infection traffic to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">8.208.24[.]139</span> using various domain names ending with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.at</span>. This category of Ursnif causes the following traffic:</p>
<ul>
<li>HTTP GET requests caused by the initial Ursnif binary</li>
<li>HTTP GET request for follow-up data, with the URL ending in <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.dat</span></li>
<li>HTTP GET and POST requests after Ursnif is persistent in the Windows registry</li>
</ul>
<p>The following HTTP data is used during the traffic in our first example:</p>
<ul>
<li>Domain for initial GET requests: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">w8.wensa[.]at</span></li>
<li>Request for follow-up data: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://api2.casys[.]at/jvassets/xI/t64.dat</span></li>
<li>Domain for GET and POST requests after Ursnif is persistent: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">h1.wensa[.]at</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Follow the TCP stream for the very first HTTP GET request at 20:13:09 UTC. The TCP stream window shows the full URL. Note how the GET request starts with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/api1/</span> and is followed by a long string of alpha-numeric characters with backslashes and underscores. Figure 4 highlights the GET request.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2218" height="1604"  class="wp-image-102534 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-45.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-45.jpeg 2218w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-45-300x217.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-45-1024x741.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-45-768x555.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-45-1536x1111.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-45-2048x1481.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-45-900x651.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-45-370x268.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2218px) 100vw, 2218px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 4. Example of an HTTP GET request caused by our first Ursnif example.</em></span></p>
<p>We can find the same pattern from Ursnif activity caused by a Hancitor infection on December 10,2019. The pcap is available <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/2019/12/10/index.html">here</a>. Mixed with the other malware activity, this December 10th example contains the following indicators for Ursnif:</p>
<ul>
<li>Domain for initial GET requests: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">foo.fulldin[.]at</span></li>
<li>Request for follow-up data: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://one.ahah100[.]at/jvassets/o1/s64.dat</span></li>
<li>Domain for GET and POST requests after Ursnif is persistent: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">api.ahah100[.]at</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Note how patterns from Ursnif traffic in the December 10th example are similar to the patterns we find in example 1. These patterns are commonly seen from Ursnif samples that do not use HTTPS traffic.</p>
<h2><a id="post-102527-_u84xdpmphasq"></a>Example 2: Ursnif with HTTPS</h2>
<p>The second pcap for this tutorial, <strong><em>Ursnif-traffic-example-2.pcap</em></strong>, is available <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/training/examining-ursnif.html">here</a>. Like our first pcap, this one has also been stripped of any traffic not related to the Ursnif infection.</p>
<p>Open the pcap in Wireshark and filter on <strong><em>http.request or ssl.handshake.type == 1</em></strong> as shown in Figure 5. If you are using Wireshark 3.0 or newer, filter on <strong><em>http.request or tls.handshake.type == 1</em></strong> for the correct results.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2452" height="1318"  class="wp-image-102536 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-46.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-46.jpeg 2452w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-46-300x161.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-46-1024x550.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-46-768x413.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-46-1536x826.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-46-2048x1101.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-46-900x484.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-46-370x199.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2452px) 100vw, 2452px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 5. The pcap for our second example filtered in Wireshark.</em></span></p>
<p>This example has the following sequence of events:</p>
<ul>
<li>HTTP GET request that returns an initial Ursnif binary</li>
<li>HTTP GET requests caused by the initial Ursnif binary</li>
<li>HTTPS traffic after Ursnif is persistent in the Windows registry</li>
</ul>
<p>Follow the TCP stream for the first HTTP GET request to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ghinatronx[.]com</span>. This TCP stream reveals a Windows executable or DLL file as shown in Figure 6. We can export the Ursnif binary from the pcap as described in<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-wireshark-exporting-objects-from-a-pcap/"> this previous tutorial</a>.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="1202" height="793"  class="wp-image-102538 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-47.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-47.jpeg 1202w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-47-300x198.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-47-1024x676.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-47-768x507.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-47-900x594.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-47-370x244.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1202px) 100vw, 1202px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 6. The first HTTP GET request returning a binary for Ursnif.</em></span></p>
<p>The next four HTTP requests to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bjanicki[.]com</span> were caused by the Ursnif binary. Follow the TCP stream for the first HTTP GET request to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bjanicki[.]com</span> at 18:46:21 UTC. This TCP stream shows the full URL. Note how the GET request starts with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/images/</span> and is followed by a long string of alpha-numeric characters with backslashes and underscores before ending with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.avi</span>. This URL pattern is somewhat similar to Ursnif traffic from our first pcap. Figure 7 highlights a GET request from our second pcap.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2262" height="1668"  class="wp-image-102540 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-48.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-48.jpeg 2262w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-48-300x221.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-48-1024x755.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-48-768x566.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-48-1536x1133.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-48-2048x1510.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-48-900x664.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-48-370x273.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2262px) 100vw, 2262px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 7. Example of an HTTP GET request from our second Ursnif example.</em></span></p>
<p>Unlike our first example, Ursnif in this second pcap generates HTTPS traffic after it becomes persistent on an infected Windows host. Use your <strong><em>basic</em></strong> web filter as described in<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-wireshark-display-filter-expressions/"> this previous tutorial</a> for a quick review of the HTTPS traffic. Note the HTTPS traffic to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">prodrigo29lbkf20[.]com</span> as shown in Figure 8.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2416" height="1316"  class="wp-image-102542 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-49.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-49.jpeg 2416w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-49-300x163.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-49-1024x558.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-49-768x418.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-49-1536x837.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-49-2048x1116.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-49-900x490.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-49-370x202.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2416px) 100vw, 2416px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 8. Filtering on web traffic in Wireshark, highlighting the HTTPS traffic generated by Ursnif.</em></span></p>
<p>HTTPS traffic generated by this Ursnif variant reveals distinct characteristics in certificates used to establish encrypted communications. To get a closer look, filter on<strong><em> ssl.handshake.type == 11</em></strong> (or <strong><em>tls.handshake.type == 11</em></strong> in Wireshark 3.0 or newer). Select the first frame in the results and go to the frame details window. There we can expand lines and work our way to the certificate issuer data. Figure 9 shows how to begin.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2490" height="1628"  class="wp-image-102544 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-50.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-50.jpeg 2490w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-50-300x196.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-50-1024x670.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-50-768x502.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-50-1536x1004.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-50-2048x1339.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-50-900x588.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-50-370x242.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2490px) 100vw, 2490px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 9. Finding our way to the certificate issuer data.</em></span></p>
<p>As shown in Figure 9, we expand the line for <strong><em>Secure Sockets Layer </em></strong>in the frame details window. For Wireshark 3.0, this line shows as <strong><em>Transport Layer Security</em></strong>. Then we expand the line labeled <strong><em>TLSv1.2 Record Layer: Handshake Protocol: Certificate</em></strong>. Then we expand the line labeled <strong><em>Handshake Protocol: Certificate</em></strong>.</p>
<p>We keep expanding, until we find our way to the certificate issuer data as shown in Figure 10.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2498" height="1622"  class="wp-image-102546 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-51.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-51.jpeg 2498w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-51-300x195.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-51-1024x665.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-51-768x499.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-51-1536x997.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-51-2048x1330.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-51-900x584.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-51-370x240.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2498px) 100vw, 2498px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 10. Certificate issuer data from HTTPS traffic caused by Ursnif.</em></span></p>
<p>In Figure 10 shown under the <strong><em>Handshake Protocol: Certificate</em></strong> line, we work our way down through the following items:</p>
<ul>
<li>Certificates (615 bytes)</li>
<li>Certificate: 30820260308201c9a003020102020900c692c94106d77dfc...</li>
<li>signedCertificate</li>
<li>Issuer: rdnSequence (6)</li>
<li>rdnSequence: 6 items (id-at-commonName=*,id-at-organizationalUnitN...</li>
</ul>
<p>Individual items under the <strong><em>rdnSequence</em></strong> line show properties of the certificate issuer. These reveal the following characteristics:</p>
<ul>
<li>countryName=<strong>XX</strong></li>
<li>stateOrProvinceName=<strong>1</strong></li>
<li>localityName=<strong>1</strong></li>
<li>organizationName=<strong>1</strong></li>
<li>organizationalUnitName=<strong>1</strong></li>
<li>commonName=<strong>*</strong></li>
</ul>
<p>This issuer data is not valid, and these patterns are commonly seen in Ursnif infections. But what does legitimate certificate data look like? Figure 11 shows valid data from a certificate issued by DigiCert.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2070" height="848"  class="wp-image-102548 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-52.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-52.jpeg 2070w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-52-300x123.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-52-1024x419.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-52-768x315.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-52-1536x629.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-52-2048x839.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-52-900x369.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-52-370x152.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2070px) 100vw, 2070px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 11. Valid certificate issuer data.</em></span></p>
<p>One last thing about Ursnif is the IP address check by an Ursnif-infected host. This happens over DNS using a resolver at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">opendns[.]com</span>. Like other IP address identifiers, this is a legitimate service. However, these services are commonly used by malware.</p>
<p>To see this IP address check, filter on <strong><em>dns.qry.name contains opendns.com</em></strong> and review the results as shown in Figure 12.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2372" height="1538"  class="wp-image-102550 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-53.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-53.jpeg 2372w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-53-300x195.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-53-1024x664.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-53-768x498.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-53-1536x996.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-53-2048x1328.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-53-900x584.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-53-370x240.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2372px) 100vw, 2372px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 12. IP address check by an Ursnif-infected Windows host.</em></span></p>
<p>As shown in Figure 12, the Window host generated a dns query for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">resolver1.opendns[.]com</span> followed by a DNS query to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">208.67.222[.]222</span> for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">myip.opendns[.]com</span>. The DNS query to<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> myip.opendns[.]com</span> returned the public IP address of the infected Windows host.</p>
<h2><a id="post-102527-_1ij7g4arl9bg"></a>Example 3: Ursnif with Follow-up Malware</h2>
<p>Our third pcap, <strong><em>Ursnif-traffic-example-3.pcap</em></strong>, is available <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/training/examining-ursnif.html">here</a>. This pcap also has unrelated activity stripped from the traffic, but it builds on our last example. Our third pcap includes what appears to be decoy traffic, and it also includes an HTTP GET request for follow-up malware. The sequence of events is:</p>
<ul>
<li>HTTP GET request that returns an initial Ursnif binary</li>
<li>HTTP GET requests caused by the initial Ursnif binary, including decoy URLs</li>
<li>HTTPS traffic after Ursnif is persistent in the Windows registry</li>
<li>HTTP GET request for follow-up malware</li>
</ul>
<p>Use your <strong><em>basic</em></strong> web filter as described in<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-wireshark-display-filter-expressions/"> this previous tutorial</a> for a quick review of the web-based traffic as shown in Figure 13.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><img width="2382" height="1550"  class="wp-image-102552 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-54.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-54.jpeg 2382w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-54-300x195.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-54-1024x666.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-54-768x500.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-54-1536x999.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-54-2048x1333.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-54-900x586.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-54-370x241.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2382px) 100vw, 2382px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 13. Filtering our third pcap for web traffic in Wireshark.</span></em></p>
<p>In Figure 13, the initial HTTP request to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sinicaleer[.]com</span> returned a Windows executable for Ursnif. The remaining traffic visible Figure 13 was caused by the Ursnif executable until it became persistent.</p>
<p>Three HTTP requests to<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> google[.]com</span> follow similar URL patterns as Ursnif traffic to an actual malicious domain of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ghdy656262oe[.]com</span>. These HTTP GET requests to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">google[.]com</span> appear to be decoy traffic, because they do not assist the infection. HTTPS traffic over TCP port 443 to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">gmail[.]com</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">www.google[.]com</span> also serves no direct purpose for the infection, and that activity could also be classified as decoy traffic. Figure 14 shows an example of the decoy HTTP GET requests to<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> google[.]com</span>.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><img width="2274" height="1556"  class="wp-image-102554 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-55.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-55.jpeg 2274w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-55-300x205.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-55-1024x701.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-55-768x526.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-55-1536x1051.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-55-2048x1401.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-55-900x616.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-55-370x253.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2274px) 100vw, 2274px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 14. Decoy HTTP GET request by the Ursnif-infected host to a Google domain.</span></em></p>
<p>Note the HTTP traffic to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ghdy656262oe[.]com</span>. The first two GET requests to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ghdy656262oe[.]com</span> return a <strong><em>404 Not Found</em></strong> response as shown in Figure 15. The third HTTP GET request returns a <strong><em>200 OK</em></strong> response, and the infection continues as shown in Figure 16.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2262" height="1552"  class="wp-image-102556 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-56.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-56.jpeg 2262w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-56-300x206.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-56-1024x703.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-56-768x527.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-56-1536x1054.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-56-2048x1405.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-56-900x618.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-56-370x254.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2262px) 100vw, 2262px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 15. First two HTTP GET requests to malicious Ursnif domain return a 404 Not Found response.</em></span></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><img width="2448" height="1544"  class="wp-image-102558 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-57.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-57.jpeg 2448w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-57-300x189.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-57-1024x646.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-57-768x484.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-57-1536x969.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-57-2048x1292.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-57-900x568.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-57-370x233.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2448px) 100vw, 2448px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 16. Some false starts before the Ursnif infection continues.</span></em></p>
<p>Since the first HTTP GET request to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ghdy656262oe[.]com</span> was not a 200 OK, the infected Windows host cycled through other malicious domains to continue the infection. These two domains are <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">tnzf3380au[.]to</span>p and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">xijamaalj[.]com</span>. However, the DNS queries for these domains returned a “No such name” in response, so the infected Windows host went back to trying <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ghdy656262oe[.]com</span>.</p>
<p>Use the following Wireshark filter to better see this sequence of events:</p>
<p><strong><em>((http.request or http.response) and ip.addr eq 194.1.236.191) or dns.qry.name contains tnzf3380au or dns.qry.name contains xijamaalj</em></strong></p>
<p>The results should appear similar to the column display in Figure 17.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2386" height="1466"  class="wp-image-102560 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-58.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-58.jpeg 2386w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-58-300x184.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-58-1024x629.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-58-768x472.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-58-1536x944.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-58-2048x1258.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-58-900x553.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-58-370x227.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2386px) 100vw, 2386px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 17. Filtering to show how the infected Windows host tries Ursnif-related domains before it hits a 200 OK in HTTP traffic.</em></span></p>
<p>To review the rest of the infection, use your <strong><em>basic</em></strong> web filter and scroll to the end of the results. Figure 18 shows the post-infection traffic after Ursnif becomes persistent.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2384" height="1472"  class="wp-image-102562 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-59.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-59.jpeg 2384w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-59-300x185.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-59-1024x632.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-59-768x474.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-59-1536x948.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-59-2048x1265.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-59-900x556.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-59-370x228.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2384px) 100vw, 2384px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 18. Post-infection traffic after Ursnif becomes persistent on the victim’s Windows host.</em></span></p>
<p>In Figure 18, after five HTTP GET requests to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ghdy656262oe[.]com</span>, we find traffic generated by the infected Windows host after Ursnif becomes persistent. This includes HTTPS traffic to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">google[.]com</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">gmail[.]com</span>.</p>
<p>Traffic to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">vnt69tnjacynthe[.]com</span> should have the same type of certificate issuer data we witnessed in our second pcap. But this traffic includes an HTTP GET request to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">carresqautomotive[.]com</span> ending with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.rar</span>.</p>
<p>This URL ending in .rar returned follow-up malware. However, this follow-up malware is encoded or otherwise encrypted when sent over the network. The binary decoded on the infected Windows host, which is not seen in the infection traffic. Follow the TCP stream for the HTTP GET request to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">carresqautomotive[.]com</span>, and you should see the same data as shown in Figure 19.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2254" height="1548"  class="wp-image-102564 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-60.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-60.jpeg 2254w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-60-300x206.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-60-1024x703.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-60-768x527.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-60-1536x1055.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-60-2048x1407.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-60-900x618.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-60-370x254.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2254px) 100vw, 2254px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 19. Follow-up malware sent to an Ursnif-infected Windows host.</em></span></p>
<p>This data is encrypted, so we cannot export a copy of the follow-up malware from the pcap. Therefore, we must rely on other post-infection traffic to determine what type of malware was sent to the Ursnif-infected host.</p>
<p>We have seen various types of follow-up malware from Ursnif infections, including <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/2019/12/02/index.html">Dridex</a>, <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/2019/10/21/index.html">IcedID</a>, <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/2019/05/03/index.html">Nymain</a>, <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/2019/07/29/index.html">Pushdo</a>, and <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/2019/09/04/index.html">Trickbot</a>.</p>
<p>Our next example is an Ursnif infection with Dridex as the follow-up malware.</p>
<h2><a id="post-102527-_en47sz7tbiqq"></a>Example 4: Ursnif Infection with Dridex</h2>
<p>Our fourth pcap, <strong><em>Ursnif-traffic-example-4.pcap</em></strong>, is available <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/training/examining-ursnif.html">here</a>. Unlike our first three examples, this pcap does not have unrelated activity stripped from the traffic.</p>
<p>Use your <strong><em>basic</em></strong> web filter to get a better idea of the traffic. Your results should appear similar to Figure 20.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><img width="2458" height="1630"  class="wp-image-102566 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-61.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-61.jpeg 2458w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-61-300x199.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-61-1024x679.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-61-768x509.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-61-1536x1019.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-61-2048x1358.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-61-900x597.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-61-370x245.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2458px) 100vw, 2458px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 20. Traffic from our fourth pcap filtered in Wireshark.</span></em></p>
<p>This pcap has the same sequence of events as our previous example, but it adds post-infection activity from the follow-up malware:</p>
<ul>
<li>HTTP GET request that returns an initial Ursnif binary</li>
<li>HTTP GET requests caused by the initial Ursnif binary, including decoy URLs</li>
<li>HTTPS traffic after Ursnif is persistent in the Windows registry</li>
<li>HTTP GET request for follow-up malware</li>
<li>Post-infection activity from the follow-up malware</li>
</ul>
<p>In this fourth example, the HTTP GET request for an initial Ursnif binary is to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">oklogallem[.]com</span>. Ursnif causes HTTP GET requests to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kh2714ldb[.]com</span> before the infection becomes persistent.</p>
<p>Figure 21 shows activity after Ursnif is persistent, where Ursnif causes HTTPS traffic to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">s9971kbjjessie[.]com</span>. We then see an HTTP GET request to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">startuptshirt[.]my</span> for the follow-up malware. Finally we find post-infection traffic caused by the follow-up malware.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><img width="2500" height="1597"  class="wp-image-102568 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-62.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-62.jpeg 2500w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-62-300x192.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-62-1024x654.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-62-768x491.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-62-1536x981.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-62-2048x1308.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-62-900x575.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-62-370x236.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2500px) 100vw, 2500px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 21. Activity from the infection after Ursnif is persistent.</span></em></p>
<p>Our fourth example follows the same infection patterns as our third pcap, but now we also have HTTPS/SSL/TLS traffic to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">94.140.114[.]6</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5.61.34[.]51</span> without any associated domain name. This is Dridex post-infection traffic.</p>
<p>Certificate issuer data for Dridex is different than certificate issuer data for Ursnif. Use the following filter to review the Dridex certificate data in our fourth pcap:</p>
<p><strong><em>(ip.addr eq 94.140.114.6 or ip.addr eq 5.61.34.51) and ssl.handshake.type eq 11</em></strong></p>
<p>Note: if you are using Wireshark 3.0 or newer, use <strong><em>tls.handshake.type </em></strong>instead of <strong><em>ssl.handshake.type</em></strong>.</p>
<p>Select the first frame in the results, go to the frame details window, and expand the certificate-related lines as shown by our second example in Figures 9 and 10. Examining certificate issuer data from our fourth pcap should look similar to Figures 22 and 23.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2464" height="1636"  class="wp-image-102570 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-63.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-63.jpeg 2464w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-63-300x199.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-63-1024x680.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-63-768x510.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-63-1536x1020.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-63-2048x1360.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-63-900x598.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-63-370x246.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2464px) 100vw, 2464px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 22. Working our way to the certificate issuer data in the Dridex traffic.</em></span></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><img width="2460" height="1632"  class="wp-image-102572 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-64.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-64.jpeg 2460w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-64-300x199.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-64-1024x679.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-64-768x510.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-64-1536x1019.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-64-2048x1359.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-64-900x597.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-64-370x245.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2460px) 100vw, 2460px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 23. Reaching the certificate issuer data from one of the Dridex IP addresses.</span></em></p>
<p>Under the <strong><em>rdnSequence</em></strong> line, we find properties of the certificate issuer. Certificate issuer characteristics for HTTPS/SSL/TLS traffic at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">94.140.114[.]6</span> follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>countryName=<strong>NP</strong></li>
<li>localityName=<strong>Kathmandu</strong></li>
<li>organizationName=<strong>Buvecoww Fftaites O.V.E.E.</strong></li>
<li>organizationalUnitName=<strong>Olfo Dusar Latha</strong></li>
<li>commonName=<strong>ndltman-dsamutb.spiegel</strong></li>
</ul>
<p>Certificate issuer data is different for<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> 5.61.34[.]51</span>, but it follows a similar style:</p>
<ul>
<li>countryName=<strong>MU</strong></li>
<li>localityName=<strong>Port Louis</strong></li>
<li>organizationName=<strong>Ppoffi Sourinop Cooperative</strong></li>
<li>organizationalUnitName=<strong>ipeepstha and thicioi</strong></li>
<li>commonName=<strong>plledsaprell.Byargt9wailen.voting</strong></li>
</ul>
<p>This type of issuer data is commonly seen for Dridex post-infection traffic. In our next example, you can further practice reviewing certificate issuer data for Dridex.</p>
<h2><a id="post-102527-_eenivuar8s5e"></a>Example 5: Evaluation</h2>
<p>The fifth pcap for this tutorial, <strong><em>Ursnif-traffic-example-5.pcap</em></strong>, is available <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/training/examining-ursnif.html">here</a>. Like our previous example, this pcap has an Ursnif infection followed by Dridex, so we can practice the skills described so far in this tutorial.</p>
<p>Based on what we have learned so far, open the fifth pcap in Wireshark, and answer the following questions:</p>
<ul>
<li>For the initial Ursnif binary, which URL returned a Windows executable file?</li>
<li>After the initial Ursnif binary was sent, the infected Windows host contacted different domains for the HTTP GET requests. Which domain was the traffic successful and allowed the infection to proceed?</li>
<li>What domain was used in HTTPS traffic after Ursnif became persistent on the infected Windows host?</li>
<li>What URL ending in .rar was used to send follow-up malware to the infected Windows host?</li>
<li>What IP addresses were used for the Dridex post-infection traffic?</li>
</ul>
<p>Answers follow.</p>
<p><strong>Q:</strong> For the initial Ursnif binary, which URL returned a Windows executable file?</p>
<p><strong>A:</strong> <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://ritalislum[.]com/obedle/zarref.php?l=sopopf8.cab</span></p>
<p>The only Windows executable file in this pcap is the initial Windows executable file for Ursnif. Use the following Wireshark search filter to quickly find this executable:</p>
<p><strong><em>ip contains "This program"</em></strong></p>
<p>This filter should provide only one frame in the results. Follow the TCP stream for this frame as shown in Figure 24.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><img width="1950" height="1322"  class="wp-image-102574 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-65.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-65.jpeg 1950w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-65-300x203.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-65-1024x694.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-65-768x521.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-65-1536x1041.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-65-900x610.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-65-370x251.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1950px) 100vw, 1950px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 24. Filtering to find a frame with the Windows executable file and following the TCP stream.</span></em></p>
<p>The TCP stream window contains the domain and URL from the GET request as shown in Figure 25.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><img width="2006" height="1416"  class="wp-image-102576 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-66.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-66.jpeg 2006w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-66-300x212.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-66-1024x723.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-66-768x542.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-66-1536x1084.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-66-900x635.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-66-370x261.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2006px) 100vw, 2006px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 25. URL info from the TCP stream.</span></em></p>
<p><strong>Q: </strong>After the initial Ursnif binary was sent, the infected Windows host contacted different domains for the HTTP GET requests. Which domain was the traffic successful and allowed the infection to proceed?</p>
<p><strong>A: </strong><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">k55gaisi[.]com</span></p>
<p>Use your <strong><em>basic</em></strong> web filter for an overview of the web traffic. HTTP requests caused by this variant of Ursnif start with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GET /images/</span> as already seen in examples two, three, and four of this tutorial. The first HTTP request to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">k55gaisi[.]com</span> at 15:36 UTC is noted in Figure 26. But if you follow the TCP stream, it shows a 404 Not Found as the response.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img width="2496" height="1606"  class="wp-image-102578 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-67.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-67.jpeg 2496w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-67-300x193.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-67-1024x659.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-67-768x494.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-67-1536x988.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-67-2048x1318.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-67-900x579.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-67-370x238.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2496px) 100vw, 2496px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Figure 26. Searching web traffic for HTTP GET requests caused by Ursnif.</em></span></p>
<p>Also shown in Figure 26, the next HTTP GET request for an Ursnif-style URL is to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bon11ljgarry[.]com</span> at 15:37 UTC. The HTTP stream for that request reveals a redirect to a URL at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">www.search-error[.]com</span>.</p>
<p>Scroll down further, and for similar traffic to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">leinwqoa[.]com</span> as noted in Figure 27.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><img width="2480" height="1542"  class="wp-image-102580 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-68.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-68.jpeg 2480w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-68-300x187.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-68-1024x637.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-68-768x478.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-68-1536x955.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-68-2048x1273.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-68-900x560.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-68-370x230.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2480px) 100vw, 2480px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 27. Finding another Ursnif-style URL that redirects to a search error page.</span></em></p>
<p>Scroll down further to find four HTTP GET requests to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">k55gaisi[.]com</span> that return 200 OK responses. From this point, the Ursnif infection proceeds, and we find no further Ursnif-style HTTP requests that start with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GET /images/</span>.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><img width="2494" height="1542"  class="wp-image-102582 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-69.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-69.jpeg 2494w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-69-300x185.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-69-1024x633.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-69-768x475.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-69-1536x950.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-69-2048x1266.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-69-900x556.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-69-370x229.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2494px) 100vw, 2494px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 28. Finding the Ursnif-style HTTP GET requests that return a 200 OK.</span></em></p>
<p><strong>Q:</strong> What domain was used in HTTPS traffic after Ursnif became persistent on the infected Windows host?</p>
<p><strong>A:</strong> <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">n9maryjanef[.]com</span></p>
<p>When Ursnif is persistent, we no longer see Ursnif-style HTTP requests starting with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GET /images/</span>. Instead, we find Ursnif-related HTTPS traffic. Shortly after the final Ursnif-style HTTP GET request, HTTPS traffic to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">n9maryjanef[.]com</span> begins on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">185.118.165[.]109</span> as highlighted in Figure 29. This is Ursnif traffic.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><img width="2500" height="1337"  class="wp-image-102584 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-70.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-70.jpeg 2500w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-70-300x160.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-70-1024x548.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-70-768x411.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-70-1536x821.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-70-2048x1095.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-70-900x481.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-70-370x198.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2500px) 100vw, 2500px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 29. HTTPS traffic caused by Ursnif.</span></em></p>
<p>You can confirm this is Ursnif traffic by filtering on <strong><em>ip.addr eq 185.118.165.109 and ssl.handshake.type == 11</em></strong> and reviewing the certificate issuer data. The certificate issuer data should look the same as our second example in Figure 10.</p>
<p><strong>Q:</strong> What URL ending in .rar was used to send follow-up malware to the infected Windows host?</p>
<p><strong>A: </strong><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://testedsolutionbe[.]com/wp-content/plugins/apikey/uaasdqweeeeqsd.rar</span></p>
<p>HTTP GET requests caused by Ursnif for follow-up malware end in .rar, so use the following filter to find this URL in our pcap:</p>
<p><strong><em>http.request and ip contains .rar</em></strong></p>
<p>The results should be similar to what we see in Figure 30.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><img width="2500" height="1508"  class="wp-image-102586 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-71.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-71.jpeg 2500w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-71-300x181.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-71-1024x618.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-71-768x463.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-71-1536x927.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-71-2048x1235.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-71-900x543.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-71-370x223.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2500px) 100vw, 2500px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 30. Finding the URL for follow-up malware from this Ursnif infection.</span></em></p>
<p>Notice in Figure 30 how the HTTP GET request in Figure 30 redirects to an HTTPS URL.</p>
<p><strong>Q:</strong> What IP addresses were used for the Dridex post-infection traffic?</p>
<p><strong>A:</strong> <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">185.99.133[.]38</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5.61.34[.]51</span></p>
<p>One of these IP addresses is the same as Dridex in our fourth pcap, and it has the same certificate issuer data. Dridex traffic to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">185.99.133[.]38</span> has the same style of certificate issuer data as seen in example 4. Traffic to both IP addresses does not involve a domain name.</p>
<p>The Dridex post-infection traffic is easy to spot in this example if we look for any HTTPS/SSL/TLS traffic without a domain after the HTTP GET request ending in <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.rar</span> as shown in Figure 31.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><img width="2482" height="1548"  class="wp-image-102588 aligncenter lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-72.jpeg" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-72.jpeg 2482w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-72-300x187.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-72-1024x639.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-72-768x479.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-72-1536x958.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-72-2048x1277.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-72-900x561.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/word-image-72-370x231.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 2482px) 100vw, 2482px" /><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Figure 31. Finding the Dridex traffic in our fifth pcap.</span></em></p>
<h2><a id="post-102527-_4ybwjcfcvss2"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>This tutorial provided tips for examining Windows infections with Ursnif malware. More pcaps with examples of Ursnif activity can be found at <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net">malware-traffic-analysis.net</a>.</p>
<p>For more help with Wireshark, see our previous tutorials:</p>
<ul>
<li style="list-style-type: none;">
<ul>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-customizing-wireshark-changing-column-display/">Customizing Wireshark – Changing Your Column Display</a></li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-wireshark-display-filter-expressions/">Using Wireshark – Display Filter Expressions</a></li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-wireshark-identifying-hosts-and-users/">Using Wireshark: Identifying Hosts and Users</a></li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-wireshark-exporting-objects-from-a-pcap/">Using Wireshark: Exporting Objects from a Pcap</a></li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wireshark-tutorial-examining-trickbot-infections/">Wireshark Tutorial: Examining Trickbot Infections</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
      
              </div>
              <!--<span class="post__date">Updated 7 June, 2024 at 7:24 AM PDT</span>-->

                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="wireshark-tutorial-examining-ursnif-infections:related-resources:Lateral Movement on macOS: Unique and Popular Techniques and In-the-Wild Examples:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-11-22T11:00:26+00:00">November 22, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unique-popular-techniques-lateral-movement-macos/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="wireshark-tutorial-examining-ursnif-infections:related-resources:Lateral Movement on macOS: Unique and Popular Techniques and In-the-Wild Examples">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Lateral Movement on macOS: Unique and Popular Techniques and In-the-Wild Examples</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/remote-code-execution/" title="Remote Code Execution" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="wireshark-tutorial-examining-ursnif-infections:related-resources:Lateral Movement on macOS: Unique and Popular Techniques and In-the-Wild Examples:Remote Code Execution">Remote Code Execution</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/python/" title="Python" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="wireshark-tutorial-examining-ursnif-infections:related-resources:Lateral Movement on macOS: Unique and Popular Techniques and In-the-Wild Examples:Python">Python</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/macos/" title="macOS" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="wireshark-tutorial-examining-ursnif-infections:related-resources:Lateral Movement on macOS: Unique and Popular Techniques and In-the-Wild Examples:macOS">MacOS</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unique-popular-techniques-lateral-movement-macos/" title="Lateral Movement on macOS: Unique and Popular Techniques and In-the-Wild Examples" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="wireshark-tutorial-examining-ursnif-infections:related-resources:Lateral Movement on macOS: Unique and Popular Techniques and In-the-Wild Examples:read now">

                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/02_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of FrostyGoop malware. Close-up view of a digital screen displaying a pixelated, abstract image, possibly representing a face." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/02_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/02_Malware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/02_Malware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/02_Malware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/02_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="wireshark-tutorial-examining-ursnif-infections:related-resources:FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-11-19T11:00:15+00:00">November 19, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/frostygoop-malware-analysis/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="wireshark-tutorial-examining-ursnif-infections:related-resources:FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications">

                    <h4 class="post-title">Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/backdoor/" title="backdoor" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="wireshark-tutorial-examining-ursnif-infections:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant:backdoor">Backdoor</a>

				</li></ul>                </div>

    <div class="l-container bs__controls">
      <div class="bs__progress"><span></span></div>
      <div class="bs__navigation"> 
        <ul>
          <li> 
            <button id="prevButton"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/slider-arrow-left.svg" alt="Slider arrow"></button>
          </li>
          <li> 
            <button id="nextButton"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/slider-arrow-left.svg" alt="Slider arrow"></button>
          </li>
        </ul>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
 
        <div class="be-enlarge-modal" id="enlargedModal">
          <div class="be-enlarge-modal__wrapper"> 
            <figure> 
              <button class="close__modal" id="closeModal">
